prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will use 1875.0 MHz bandwidth in dual polarization mode that is sufficient to cover the extended outflow component at high velocity (~1000 km/s) from the center of (Geach et al. 2014).
Considering the expected velocity width of 120 km/s (FWHM), a velocity resolution of ~11 km/s is appropriate.
As we expect the molecular outflow of the blobs to be extended, the requested anular resolution of 1.0 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the target and extended outflow component.

We request the above RMS to reach Sigma_H2 = 5 Msun/yr/pc2 at 5sigma level assuming velocity resolution of dv=5km/s. With this depth, we expect to detect CO(J=2-1) emission at the center of this blob at 200sigma level and extended molecular outflow component with S/N 5-6 times lower than the center (Geach et al. 2014) at 30sigma level.

We will use 937.5 MHz bandwidth in dual polarization mode, because the CO line redshifted to the edge of the band in that we cannot use 1875.0 MHz bandwith. However, it is still sufficient to cover the extended outflow component at high velocity (~1000 km/s) from the center of (Geach et al. 2014).
Considering the expected velocity width of ~340 km/s (FWHM), a velocity resolution of ~4.66 km/s is more than enough.
As we expect the molecular outflow of the blobs to be extended, the requested anular resolution of 1.0 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the target and extended outflow component.

We request the above RMS to reach Sigma_H2 = 5 Msun/yr/pc2 at 5sigma level assuming velocity resolution of dv=5km/s. With this depth, we expect to detect CO(J=2-1) emission at the center of this blob at 134sigma level and extended molecular outflow component with S/N 5-6 times lower than the center (Geach et al. 2014) at 23sigma level.

We will use 1875.0 MHz bandwidth in dual polarization mode that is sufficient to cover the extended outflow component at high velocity (~1000 km/s) from the center of (Geach et al. 2014).
Considering the expected velocity width of 110 km/s (FWHM), a velocity resolution of ~8 km/s is appropriate.
As we expect the molecular outflow of the blobs to be extended, the requested anular resolution of 1.0 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the target and extended outflow component.

We request the above RMS to reach Sigma_H2 = 5 Msun/yr/pc2 at 5sigma level assuming velocity resolution of dv=5km/s. With this depth, we expect to detect CO(J=2-1) emission at the center of this blob at 81sigma level and extended molecular outflow component with S/N 5-6 times lower than the center (Geach et al. 2014) at 14sigma level.

We will use 1875.0 MHz bandwidth in dual polarization mode that is sufficient to cover the extended outflow component at high velocity (~1000 km/s) from the center of (Geach et al. 2014).
Considering the expected velocity width of 100 km/s (FWHM), a velocity resolution of ~11 km/s is appropriate.
As we expect the molecular outflow of the blobs to be extended, the requested anular resolution of 1.0 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the target and extended outflow component.

We request the above RMS to reach Sigma_H2 = 5 Msun/yr/pc2 at 5sigma level assuming velocity resolution of dv=5km/s. With this depth, we expect to detect CO(J=2-1) emission at the center of this blob at 56sigma level and extended molecular outflow component with S/N 5-6 times lower than the center (Geach et al. 2014) at 9sigma level.

We will use 1875.0 MHz bandwidth in dual polarization mode that is sufficient to cover the extended outflow component at high velocity (~1000 km/s) from the center of (Geach et al. 2014).
Considering the expected velocity width of 500 km/s (FWHM), a velocity resolution of ~11 km/s is great.
As we expect the molecular outflow of the blobs to be extended, the requested anular resolution of 1.0 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the target and extended outflow component.

We request the above RMS to reach Sigma_H2 = 5 Msun/yr/pc2 at 5sigma level assuming velocity resolution of dv=5km/s. With this depth, we expect to detect CO(J=2-1) emission at the center of this blob at 123sigma level and extended molecular outflow component with S/N 5-6 times lower than the center (Geach et al. 2014) at 20sigma level.

We will use 468.75 MHz bandwidth in dual polarization mode, because the CO line redshifted to the edge of the band in that we cannot use 1875.0 MHz or 937.5 MHz bandwith. It might not be sufficient to cover high velocity component, but it is enough for detecting CO emission at the center of the blob.
As we expect the molecular outflow of the blobs to be extended, the requested anular resolution of 1.0 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the target and extended outflow component.

We request the above RMS to reach Sigma_H2 = 5 Msun/yr/pc2 at 5sigma level assuming velocity resolution of dv=5km/s. With this depth, we expect to detect CO(J=2-1) emission at the center of this blob at 120sigma level and extended molecular outflow component with S/N 5-6 times lower than the center (Geach et al. 2014) at 20sigma level.

We will use 1875.0 MHz bandwidth in dual polarization mode that is sufficient to cover the extended outflow component at high velocity (~1000 km/s) from the center of (Geach et al. 2014).
Considering the expected velocity width of 200 km/s (FWHM), a velocity resolution of ~8 km/s is appropriate.
As we expect the molecular outflow of the blobs to be extended, the requested anular resolution of 1.0 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the target and extended outflow component.

We request the above RMS to reach Sigma_H2 = 5 Msun/yr/pc2 at 5sigma level assuming velocity resolution of dv=5km/s. With this depth, we expect to detect CO(J=2-1) emission at the center of this blob at 30sigma level and extended molecular outflow component with S/N 5-6 times lower than the center (Geach et al. 2014) at 5sigma level.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA observations in band 3 and 4 for CO(J=2-1) emission of seven galaxies at z~1 with a large (30-75 kpc) extended [OII]3727 or [OIII]5007 nebula, dubbed oxygen blobs, that are rare objects discovered by unique Subaru wide-field imaging. Optical spectroscopy has revealed gas outflow of 200-600 km/s, and found an AGN in one blob but no AGN in the others having intense star-formation (SF). These galaxies may be experiencing the final stage of SF activities with their cold gas heated and expelled out by AGN/supernova feedback. Our ALMA program aims to investigate molecular gas of the oxygen blobs and trace the extended components of molecular outflow. We expect to detect the molecular core and extended components at >30sigma and >5sigma level, respectively, with ~30 minutes on each target. We will study kinematic properties of CO emission and associated outflow. We will also be able to discuss the difference between AGN and supernova-driven feedback with our seven oxygen blobs with and without AGN. The powerful combination of unique Subaru data and ALMA observations could uncover molecular outflow at high redshifts.
